sections.title: About the Yala National park
sections.content: Yala National Park, situated in the southeast corner of Sri Lanka, stands as the country's premier wildlife sanctuary and one of the oldest national parks in Sri Lanka. Renowned for its diverse ecosystems and rich biodiversity, Yala spans across 979 square kilometers, encompassing a mix of dense jungles, scrublands, and coastal regions. The park is particularly celebrated for its thriving population of Sri Lankan elephants, leopards, and a myriad of other fascinating wildlife species. Yala's distinctiveness lies in its classification as a key biodiversity hotspot, hosting a variety of ecosystems that support a wide array of flora and fauna.

sections.title: Location of Yala National Park
sections.content: Yala National Park is located in the southeastern part of Sri Lanka. The park spans across the Southern and Uva provinces. The main entrance to Yala National Park is typically accessed through the town of Tissamaharama.
